posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked:
I’ve been working on implementing a capstan drive reduction system for low-load applications requiring high precision position control. I’ve tested it on a model available at [link], and the initial results are impressive – no discernible backlash and an 8:1 reduction ratio.

The system features a hand-cranked version, which performs well under operational conditions. The reduction mechanism is efficient, and the lack of backlash indicates smooth operation suitable for precise positioning tasks.

The system has potential applications in areas like wrist and turret mechanisms. While I’ve focused on the hand-cranked version, full testing and evaluation are pending.

Currently, I’m developing a direct-driven Kraken capstan with a modified design incorporating a 2mm Dyneema line equipped with end-eye splice attachments instead of traditional knots.

This innovative approach could potentially be integrated into competition robots, though more research is needed. At the very least, it offers an engaging project for my desk.

As noted, this technology isn’t entirely new, but its adaptability makes it worth exploring further.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
We are busy preparing for SFR, however to give you some approximate answers:  
We don’t have an exact measurement for backlash, but we believe we targeted a 1st mode (up and down) natural frequency of ~5hz worst case this year. For reference, we measured the 2018 robot as having a 1st mode natural frequency of 3.5hz. We also had a 2nd mode (left and right) natural frequency target of 10hz.

posts.name: Tinnittin
posts.cooked: This is great! Reminds me of a video on the capstan drive I saw recently. It had a particularly thorough exploration of the design of the mechanism. Here’s a link to the video: [youtube video link].

posts.name: Lavi Arzi
posts.cooked: Natural Frequency Talk?

posts.name: Riley Brewer
posts.cooked: Sam: The reduction is around 8:1. Out of curiosity, how did you go about measuring this? How far is it from what you intended?

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: It’s the ratio of the sheave diameter to the capstan. In reality, the non-planar motion of the rope makes the calculation more complex. I guess you need to account for the helical travel path. I don’t care to go down that math rabbit hole. I’m content to slap an encoder on the wrist or whatever and ignore the actual ratio.

The natural frequency is one of the key parameters in second-order linear ordinary differential equations in standard form. It represents the square root of the ratio between stiffness and mass. Additionally, it corresponds to the frequency at which the system naturally oscillates in the absence of damping. In FIRST Robotics Competition applications, higher natural frequencies imply faster dynamics, though understanding this concept requires familiarity with system dynamics and classical control theory.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked: If you perturb the system and observe its resulting vibrations, what is the lowest frequency at which noticeable movement occurs? Mechanically, this reflects the system's stiffness level. Controls-wise, this establishes the maximum rate at which the actuator can adjust outputs while maintaining synchronization between input and response, as well as preventing self-oscillation.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: In the applications of FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC), you want higher natural frequencies because it means your dynamics are faster, however, it’s not something I would account for when designing unless you are both familiar with system dynamics and classical control theory, where this type of content is usually taught. Keep your dang control theory out of my wrench turner thread!

Control theory extends system dynamics with shared mathematical foundations, focusing on modifying system behavior through controlled adjustments rather than uncontrolled natural dynamics. Integration into mechanical engineering curricula often includes mandatory control courses, reflecting its foundational role in system design. Capstans exhibit interesting dynamic properties worth exploring.

Designing a control system alongside the mechanical system yields optimal results, as both share similar objectives and principles. Effective systems thrive when their dynamics align with control requirements, particularly emphasizing natural frequency characteristics. While rare, such integrated designs are highly beneficial, as evidenced by the example of FIRST Robotics Competition teams prioritizing cohesively designed systems.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked:
After coming across 1477’s offseason capstan elevator I had to try my hand at making my own. So far I’ve got a hand-cranked version that works pretty well. This style of capstan winch could be great for various linear tasks  

I’m playing with the sheave geometry currently using combs like they did but experimenting with helical spool geometry as well  

I’ve designed a couple of potential continuous elevator gearboxes one with fixed geometry and another adding a daughter plate for the motors to accommodate different ratios  

I’m not fully satisfied with either design yet

link_counts.title: 1477 - Configurable Capstan Driven Round Tube Elevator
Internal Elevator Rigging: A Simplified Approach Based on SDS Elevator Blocks

posts.name: pryland
posts.cooked: An interesting design indeed. While it is workable, it does not use the capstan for gear reduction. The inclusion of spur gears introduces backlash, something we were attempting to eliminate.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: The capstan diameter is a component of the overall reduction. This design (1.125" effective OD) is based around 1/2" hex and COTS print adapters. The capstan elevators utilize spur gears which introduce minimal backlash. For the rotary actuator I agree with the idea of avoiding single-stage spur gears due to potential issues. There’s no spooling or jackshafts involved in this continuous elevator system.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: The way I wanted to rig this would have required ropes to span the entire robot anyway. So I changed the design slightly to maintain pass-through capability but simplify the rigging. The rope routing is influenced by the 254 2018 Team Robot. The up ropes will be attached to springs on the carriage, while the down ropes will be tensioned together at the base. The actual rope path isn't flat. I think having enough wrap on a single capstan could make this work. If more friction is needed, adding another capstan and a figure-eight arrangement below the first one might help.

link_counts.title: Internal Elevator Rigging: A Simplified Approach Based on SDS Elevator Blocks

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: I built a 3D printed small-scale version of the elevator. It performs very well. I am currently developing an additional stage. I am quite satisfied with its current functionality. If the 2025 era requires an elevator, I will consider this concept closely.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: I never posted video of the wrist mechanism with motor control; it’s pretty much a 1:1 copy of Aaed’s model.

posts.name: Ed Peters
posts.cooked: @clydefrog88 - Can I ask what kind of motors, controllers, etc., did you use in your baby capstan? I'd like to build something like that too, but I'm only familiar with the roboRIO and WPiLB along with their respective kits, and I don't have access to those kinds of components at home.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: I used the same ODrive S1 and a random kV brushless hobby motor. That baby capstan design is cool to play with but it’s definitely a toy. I moved on with fabrication of the real deal, or at least the plates screwed to a 2x4.

posts.name: jgwentworth96
posts.cooked: Yes.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: We didn't use an elevator this season and moved on from that design. We did build it but it was never integrated into a robot. The next iteration is based on this design and is discussed a bit in that thread.
